headline: Psalm of Dreams
description: A raw psalm recounting a night vision of temptation and shame, where the red-haired woman and her twin emerge as embodiments of shadow desire. The work captures the fever of relapse into old cravings, contrasted with the voice of God asking for truth and denial of false power. It records the inner dislodging before change, the breaking point of fever in the Ash Moon.
author: Aleksandr Agnitio
whyItMatters: This psalm crystallizes the experience of inner fever — the hallucinatory pull of old patterns breaking against the will to remain true. It reveals the paradox of longing for what destroys, yet standing in God’s call to deny it. Naming the fever is itself the act of loosening its grip, preserving the tension between shame and salvation.

motifMap.meaning: Temptation, shadow of desire, recurring figure
Conscience, radical honesty, breaking of fever

articleExcerpt: The dreams of evil are upon me… They come in the shape of my seductress. They are pleasure and pain in equal measure.
sourceFragments: The dreams of evil are upon me…
God talks to me when I awake, asking me: 'Do you want this?'
Today I find missing pieces of myself, consumed by the woman with red hair.
I see the wretch that lives in me.

associatedMedia.description: Painting-like image of a kneeling man reaching upward as a red-haired woman rises in smoke before a cross of light.
